email.title: Weekly Digest

image.alt: Photo of digestive biscuits on a plate
image.title: /Digest/ives!

email.text:
Hi again! It's time for another digest.
In the past week, we held four events: the Mums and Dads meeting, Linux talk, Sponsors' Exhibition and the Bloomberg Decentralised App Development workshop. These events were an overwhelming success with a total attendee count over all four events of 1000. The Sponsors' Exhibition in particular saw an incredible 500 members attending. Thanks to everyone who participated and a special thanks to all of our volunteers!
It would be very appreciated if you could provide your feedback for the Sponsors' Exhibition through this [link](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe5Yl4yNZcXLr8x6gdjC5mLl8K_zU0UFQXWaO23iI1lIUqh6w/viewform) so that we can improve our main industrial event next year!
All of our industrial events are catered (usually with pizza). If you have any dietary requirements and if you are planning on attending an event, please make sure you [get in touch](mailto:docsoc@imperial.ac.uk) at least two days before the event to tell us. You can use the same email address to give us any feedback about our events as well! Additionally, if you want to help out at our events, be sure to join our [DoCSoc: Operations](https://www.facebook.com/groups/1509850436007222/) Facebook group.
In the coming week, we have our first inaugural bar night of the year, the Welcome Bar Night, so stay tuned for more information, more industrial events and opportunities from our sponsors.
Finally, make sure you submit your vote for the Union Autumn Elections at https://vote.union.ic.ac.uk/ before Friday 12pm!
email.heading: Sponsors' Portal
email.text:
We have released the DoCSoc Sponsors Portal, our website where you can find out more details about our sponsors, read their blog posts and see their open internship/placement positions. You can also upload your CV and directly apply to all of our Gold and Silver tier sponsors!
You can access the portal at: https://portal.docsoc.co.uk
email.heading: Welcome Bar Night

event.text:
It's time for DoCSoc's first bar night of the year: The Welcome Bar Night!
Come along for free drinks and to say hi to our new freshers or catch up with friends - it's sure to be a night you don't want to miss out on.
Drinks tokens will be given upon entry for FREE to all DoCSoc members.
At the event we will also announce the winners of our End of Year Survey, Speed Typing competition at the Freshers' Fair and the Mums and Dads Checklist!

email.heading: Palantir - Interpreting Law and Policy as Technologists

event.text:
In May 2018, the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) became one of the most important reforms of data protection law worldwide. Strangely, this law did not come with technical specifications. Join Paula Kift, of the Privacy and Civil Liberties team at Palantir, for a workshop that aims to highlight for those interested in the intersection of law and technology how they can shape it in practice, while tackling some of the most important privacy challenges of our time.
Food and drinks provided!
**Please RSVP using the link provided** before clicking 'Going' on Facebook.

email.heading: Netcraft - Cryptocurrencies for Fun and Profit

event.text:
Rolling your own cryptocurrency: what could possibly go wrong?
Over the past few years, the popularity and value of cryptocurrencies, such as Bitcoin, has soared. Bitcoin has also spawned a number of spinoff currencies, known as 'altcoins'. Some altcoins provide genuine technical improvements over Bitcoin; however, most are forks with minimal changes - designed to be pump and dump schemes to enrich their creators.
In July 2018 Imperial College jointly published a report written by Prof William Knottenbelt with eToro, a cryptocurrency exchange. The report was widely regarded by the press to be a puff piece promoting cryptocurrencies, poorly disguised as academic research. The Financial Times dubbed it "cryptopuff".
Not wanting to miss out on the fun (or profit!), Netcraft has designed its own cryptocurrency and named it Cryptopuff in tribute to Prof Knottenbelt's report. However, Cryptopuff was written in a rush during a single weekend - who knows what vulnerabilities may be lurking in its depths?
Your challenge, after a short talk illustrating the concepts, is to compete against your peers to earn as much Cryptopuff as possible.
You'll need to find and exploit vulnerabilities to steal coins from your peers, while also defending your own node against attack to protect your own coins. Or perhaps you could sell 'zero-day' vulnerabilities to other teams rather than doing the dirty work of exploiting them yourself.
The team with the greatest number of coins at the end of the event will be declared the winner.
To take part, bring your own laptop with a web browser and an SSH client (e.g. Putty http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/ for Windows users; OpenSSH for Linux/Mac users)
**There will a free bar night at the Union Bar after the competition.**

email.heading: Next Jump Opportunities
email.text:
It was great speaking to many of you at the DoCSoc careers fair on Tuesday. Hope you managed to swipe some orange sunglasses before they ran out üï∂Ô∏è! Our fast track applications for intern/placement and full time software developers are still open ‚Äì use the link below to apply to come to our Super Saturday.
https://nextjump.applytojob.com/apply/UWulrrsRCG/Software-Engineer-Web-Applications?source=socmedpost
Next Jump is a global e-commerce company and work with 70% of the Fortune 1000, generating $2.5B a year. We build coders who lead. This means not just building awesome products (in React Native, Golang and PHP), our developers lead teams to design, build and market to our 3mil UK customers ‚Äì from their first day on the job. Check out the video below to find out more about being a developer at Next Jump https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xEYu7kOsRWI
You can also email us at teamukrecruitment@nextjump.com if you have any questions.
email.heading: Schlumberger Meet & Engage Event

event.text:
We have selected DoCSoc's members to participate in an exclusive live video chat on the World Alliance for Efficient Solutions!
Many innovative solutions exist that can reduce our impact on the environment while enabling economic development.
Join Bertrand Piccard, the man who flew 26,000 miles around the world with a plane powered only by the sun and find out how he is contributing to improve the world‚Äôs energy efficiency and have economy and ecology work hand-in-hand. Learn more about his [#1000 Efficient Solutions initiative](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3RkXldC2nJI&feature=youtu.be), why innovative companies like Schlumberger are partnering with him, and how you can apply your engineering and science skills to help this important project.
**Please kindly confirm your availability by registering on the above link.**

email.heading: Algothon 2018 at BlackRock

event.location: BlackRock, Drapers Gardens, 12 Throgmorton Avenue, London, EC2N 2DL
event.text:
Algothon 2018 in partnership with BlackRock is the inaugural event of the 2018/19 academic year organised by the Imperial College Algorithmic Trading Society. We‚Äôre excited to bring you 24 hours of intense hacking, bringing 200 of the brightest minds together to produce incredible new financial technology.
This will be an incredible weekend, producing amazing new technologies, learning from some of the best minds in the field, and overall having a great time!

email.heading: 2018 Milner Award Lecture - When to trust a self-driving car

event.location: The Royal Society, London, 6-9 Carlton House Terrace, London, SW1Y 5AG
event.text:
2018 Milner Award Lecture given by Professor Marta Kwiatkowska.
How can we ensure system correctness in the presence of uncertainty?
Computing devices support us in almost all everyday tasks, from mobile phones and online banking to wearable and implantable medical devices. We are now experimenting with self‚Äìdriving cars and robots.
Since embedded software at the heart of these devices must behave correctly in presence of uncertainty, probabilistic verification techniques have been developed to guarantee their safety, reliability and resource efficiency.
Using illustrative examples, this lecture will give an overview of the role that probabilistic modelling and verification can play in a variety of applications, including security, medical devices, self-driving cars and DNA computing. It will also describe recent developments towards model synthesis, which aims to build these systems so that they are correct by construction. Finally, it will explore the problems of ensuring that systems that rely on learning will behave correctly, both in situations that they have seen in training, and in situations that they haven‚Äôt.
The prize lecture will be webcast live and the video recording of the event will be available shortly after the event.
